Thus, proteins that bind to or utilize aminoacyl-tRNAs or formylaminoacyl-tRNAs as substrates are quite sensitive to the nature of the amino acid attached to the tRNA.The binding (KDapp, 27 nm) of the U35A36 mutant Gln-tRNAfMet to EF-Tu·GTP is slightly stronger than that of the G72 mutant Met-tRNAfMet (KDapp, 34.8 nm) (Table III), yet the U35A36 mutant tRNAfMet is essentially inactive as an elongator tRNAin vivo (Table I), whereas the G72 mutant is active as an elongator in vitro (10Seong B.L. RajBhandary U.L. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1987; 84: 8859-8863Crossref PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar). The reason for it is that despite its relatively strong affinity for EF-Tu, the U35A36 mutant tRNA is a good substrate for MTF and therefore is formylated in vivoto fGln-tRNA. Because the amino group of glutamine is blocked in fGln-tRNA, this tRNA now binds very poorly to EF-Tu and cannot, in any case, participate in the elongation reaction on the ribosome because of the blocked amino group. In strains severely deficient in MTF, however, the U35A36 mutant initiator tRNA does act weakly as an elongator tRNA (55Guillon J.M. Mechulam Y. Blanquet S. Fayat G. J. Bacteriol. 1993; 175: 4507-4514Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Similarly, mutant tRNAs that are extremely poor substrates for MTF can act as elongators in vivo, albeit weakly, even though they contain a C1xA72 mismatch (56Li S. Kumar N.V. Varshney U. RajBhandary U.L. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 1022-1028Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (27) Google Scholar). These results highlight yet another important role of formylation of the initiator tRNA in ensuring sequestration of the tRNA for initiation.The strong effect of methionine in modulating the binding affinity of Met-tRNAfMet for EF-Tu highlights yet another important reason why methionine is the best amino acid for the initiation of protein synthesis in E. coli. Initiation requires formylation of the initiator Met-tRNA to fMet-tRNA by MTF. The formyl group then acts as a positive determinant for IF2. We and others (47Varshney U. Lee C.P. RajBhandary U.L. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1993; 90: 2305-2309Crossref PubMed Scopus (51) Google Scholar, 48Wu X.Q. Iyengar P. RajBhandary U.L. EMBO J. 1996; 15: 4734-4739Crossref PubMed Scopus (29) Google Scholar, 49Giege R. Ebel J.P. Clark B.F. FEBS Lett. 1973; 30: 291-295Crossref PubMed Scopus (36) Google Scholar) have shown that MTF prefers methionine over all the other amino acids tested. Similarly, IF2 also prefers formylmethionine over several other formyl amino acids tested (51Wu X.Q. RajBhandary U.L. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 1891-1895Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (50) Google Scholar). Our finding that EF-Tu binds extremely poorly to the wild type Met-tRNAfMet but binds quite well to the U35A36 mutant Gln-tRNAfMet provides yet another role for methionine in minimizing the affinity of the initiator Met-tRNAfMet for EF-Tu. This allows MTF, which is present in extremely small amounts in E. coli (57Meinnel T. Blanquet S. J. Bacteriol. 1993; 175: 7737-7740Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), to compete for Met-tRNAfMet with EF-Tu, which is the most abundant protein in E. coli (58Hershey J.W.B. Niehardt F.C. Ingraham J.L. Low K.B. Magasanik B. Schaechter M. Umbarger H.E. Escherichia coli and Salmonella typhimurium. 1. American Society for Microbiology, Washington, D. C.1987: 613-647Google Scholar). Finally, although fMet-tRNAfMet is not a substrate for peptidyl-tRNA hydrolase (59Kössel H. RajBhandary U.L. J. Mol. Biol. 1968; 35: 539-560Crossref PubMed Scopus (83) Google Scholar), Varshney and co-workers (54Thanedar S. Kumar N.V. Varshney U. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 20361-20367Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (13) Google Scholar) have shown that the U35A36 mutant fGln-tRNAfMet is a substrate for peptidyl-tRNA hydrolase. Thus, methionine plays yet another important role in ensuring the availability of fMet-tRNA for initiation by preventing its hydrolysis by peptidyl-tRNA hydrolase. A special methionine tRNA is used for the initiation of protein synthesis in all organisms studied (1Clark B.F. Marcker K.A. J. Mol. Biol. 1966; 17: 394-406Crossref PubMed Scopus (145) Google Scholar, 2Kozak M. Microbiol. Rev. 1983; 47: 1-45Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 3RajBhandary U.L. Chow C.M. Söll D. RajBhandary U.L. tRNA: Structure, Biosynthesis, and Function. American Society for Microbiology, Washington, D. C.1995: 511-528Google Scholar). The initiator tRNA is used for the initiation of protein synthesis, whereas the elongator tRNA is used for the insertion of methionine into internal peptidic linkages. Because of their unique function, initiator tRNAs, tRNAfMetin eubacteria and tRNAiMet in eukaryotes, have several properties that are different from those of elongator tRNAs (3RajBhandary U.L. Chow C.M. Söll D. RajBhandary U.L. tRNA: Structure, Biosynthesis, and Function. American Society for Microbiology, Washington, D. C.1995: 511-528Google Scholar, 4RajBhandary U.L. J. Bacteriol. 1994; 176: 547-552Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). 1) Initiator tRNAs bind directly to the P site of the ribosome in a reaction facilitated by the initiation factors, IF2 in eubacteria and eIF2 in eukaryotes. In contrast, elongator tRNAs bind to the A site of the ribosome. 2) Initiator tRNAs are used exclusively for the initiation of protein synthesis. This is achieved by preventing the binding of initiator methionyl-tRNAs to the elongation factors (EF1-Tu in eubacteria and eEF1 in eukaryotes), which carry aminoacyl-tRNAs to the A site on the ribosome (3RajBhandary U.L. Chow C.M. Söll D. RajBhandary U.L. tRNA: Structure, Biosynthesis, and Function. American Society for Microbiology, Washington, D. C.1995: 511-528Google Scholar). In eubacteria, such as Escherichia coli, the initiator Met-tRNAfMet is formylated to formylmethionyl-tRNAfMet (fMet-tRNAfMet) by methionyl-tRNA formyltransferase (5Marcker K.A. Sanger F. J. Mol. Biol. 1964; 8: 835-840Crossref PubMed Scopus (152) Google Scholar, 6Dickerman H.W. Steers E. Redfield B.G. Weissbach H. J. Biol. Chem. 1967; 242: 1522-1525Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The formyl group acts as a positive determinant for IF2 (7Canonaco M.A. Calogero R.A. Gualerzi C.O. FEBS Lett. 1986; 207: 198-204Crossref PubMed Scopus (36) Google Scholar, 8Sundari R.M. Stringer E.A. Schulman L.H. Maitra U. J. Biol. Chem. 1976; 251: 3338-3345Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Concomitantly, it makes the fMet-tRNAfMet an even worse substrate for EF-Tu (9Nissen P. Kjeldgaard M. Thirup S. Polekhina G. Reshetnikova L. Clark B.F. Nyborg J. Science. 1995; 270: 1464-1472Crossref PubMed Scopus (798) Google Scholar), thereby ensuring sequestration of the initiator tRNA exclusively for initiation. Initiator tRNAs also possess unique sequence and/or structural features that are absent in elongator tRNAs. One of the unique features of eubacterial initiator tRNAfMet (Fig. 1) is the presence of a base pair mismatch between nucleotides 1 and 72 in the acceptor stem (C1xA72). Elongator tRNAs have Watson-Crick base pairs between these positions. It was shown earlier (10Seong B.L. RajBhandary U.L. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1987; 84: 8859-8863Crossref PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar, 11Seong B.L. Lee C.P. RajBhandary U.L. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 264: 6504-6508Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) that this mismatch in the acceptor stem is a primary determinant for exclusion of tRNAfMet from elongation. U1 and G72 mutations that generate a Watson-Crick base pair at this position allow the mutant tRNAs to bind to EF-Tu and act as elongators, whereas a U1G72 double mutation, which generates a U·G wobble base pair, does not (11Seong B.L. Lee C.P. RajBhandary U.L. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 264: 6504-6508Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar,12Seong B.L. RajBhandary U.L. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1987; 84: 334-338Crossref PubMed Scopus (104) Google Scholar). Eukaryotic initiator tRNAs also have highly conserved nucleotides at position 1 and 72.
